definition: Google's agentic AI IDE that lets you build tools and automate tasks through conversation
Building software through natural language conversation with an AI agent rather than writing code manually
An AI that can take actions on your computer — running commands, editing files, browsing the web — not just answer questions
The instruction or request you type to tell the agent what to do
Everything the agent knows about your project — open files, conversation history, project structure
A text-based interface for running commands on your computer; the agent uses it to execute tasks
A simple text formatting language using symbols like # for headings and * for bold, readable as plain text
Version control system that tracks changes to your files, like a detailed undo history for your entire project
A website that stores Git repositories online, enabling backup, sharing, and collaboration
A package manager for macOS that installs developer tools via terminal commands
Windows Subsystem for Linux — lets you run Linux tools on Windows, needed for some developer workflows
Your own computer acting as a web server — lets you preview websites before publishing them
A free hosting service that publishes your website to the internet
A feature where the agent creates a detailed plan before executing, used for complex multi-step projects
The system that controls what the agent can do without asking — from asking every time to full auto mode
The framing that you are a film director and the AI agent is your production crew — you decide what to build, they handle the technical execution
Google's AI service that lets you add AI capabilities (text generation, image analysis) to your apps
Google's web-based prototyping environment for building AI-powered apps, often a starting point before moving to local development
